keyTakeAways: Walmart has paused job offers to foreign applicants requiring H-1B visas following President Donald Trump’s announcement of a $100,000 fee on H-1B visas.
The H-1B visa program is crucial for U.S. companies to access high-skilled foreign workers, particularly in tech and e-commerce sectors.
Walmart, the largest private-sector employer in the U.S., currently employs over 2,000 H-1B visa holders and is adjusting its hiring practices in response to the new visa fee.
The $100,000 fee is intended to curb abuse of the H-1B program but may disproportionately affect skilled professionals from India, who have historically made up the majority of approved applicants.
This policy shift signals broader economic and labor market impacts, as major firms reassess their global talent strategies under stricter immigration regulations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Walmart, the largest private-sector employer in the United States, has paused job offers to foreign applicants requiring H-1B visas after President Donald Trump announced a $100,000 fee on these work visas. This policy shift, which follows widespread economic concern over the program’s cost to companies, reflects growing disruption in the U.S. labor market. The H-1B visa program, used extensively by tech firms and e-commerce platforms like Walmart and Amazon, is vital for maintaining access to high-skilled talent. The new fee, intended to curb perceived abuse, is expected to disproportionately impact skilled professionals from India, who have historically dominated H-1B approvals. The move signals a significant shift in U.S. immigration policy with potentially far-reaching effects on business innovation, job creation, and global competitiveness.
title: Walmart halts job offers for applicants who need H-1B visas after Trump raises fees to $100,000
